paper_name: Graph Neural Networks for Graphs with Heterophily: A Survey
method_summary: The paper provides a systematic taxonomy of heterophilic GNNs, categorizing existing models into two major classes: non-local neighbor extension methods and GNN architecture refinement methods. Non-local neighbor extension methods aim to redefine the neighborhood of a node to include non-local neighbors, thereby allowing the aggregation of information from nodes that may not be immediately adjacent. The techniques here include high-order neighbor mixing and potential neighbor discovery. On the other hand, GNN architecture refinement methods focus on enhancing the message passing and update mechanisms to improve the learning of representations on heterophilic graphs. These methods adaptively weight messages based on the similarity of neighboring nodes, segregate ego node representations from their neighbors, and consider inter-layer combinations to better exploit the information contained in multi-layer architectures.
experiment_summary: The paper outlines various benchmarks for evaluating heterophilic GNNs, indicating that most current studies perform experiments on several well-known datasets to validate their methods. The authors also illustrate the limitations of existing datasets, emphasizing the need for comprehensive and large-scale benchmarking frameworks to facilitate research in heterophilic settings. Furthermore, it discusses the shortcomings of existing evaluation criteria and outlines future directions for developing more robust metrics.
